title: Worklog

Week 1: Getting familiar with AWS and basic AWS services
Week 2: Practicing with technologies and understanding basic AWS services
Week 3: Deep dive into IAM Security and EC2 Compute
Week 4: Mastering S3 Storage and Lifecycle Policies

title: Introduction
content:
Build a Basic AWS VPC with Public & Private Subnets In this workshop, you will build a simple network foundation in AWS using Amazon VPC (Virtual Private Cloud). The goal is to help beginners understand how networking works in the cloud, and how different components connect together to form a secure, controlled environment.
You will create a VPC with two subnets:
A Public Subnet ‚Äì allows resources (like EC2 instances) to access the Internet directly. A Private Subnet ‚Äì isolated from the public Internet by default for better security. To enable the private subnet to download packages and access online services without being exposed publicly, you will configure:
An Internet Gateway (IGW) ‚Äì allows public subnet traffic to flow to/from the Internet. An NAT Gateway ‚Äì lets instances in the private subnet access the Internet indirectly, without assigning a public IP. By the end, you will spin up two EC2 instances ‚Äî one in each subnet ‚Äî and test communication between them while observing the role of routing and gateways.
This hands-on workshop teaches essential AWS networking fundamentals through guided steps and console navigation. Perfect for beginners who want to build confidence working with VPCs.

title: Week 1 Worklog
content:
Week 1 Objectives: Connect and network with members of First Cloud Journey. Learn about the office rules and procedures for going to the workplace. Learn how to structure and write Internship Report. Gain foundational knowledge of AWS services and practice using the Console and CLI. Build and configure VPC components (Subnets, Route Tables, IGW, Security Groups, NACLs). Launch and manage EC2 instances (AMI, EBS, Elastic IP, SSH access). Learn how to clean up resources properly to avoid unnecessary charges. Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference Material 1 - Connect with members of First Cloud Journey - Read and follow the internship unit‚Äôs rules and regulations 09/07/2025 09/07/2025 FCJ Policies 2 - Get to know the office rules and how to navigate workplace procedures - Explore how to structure and write your Internship Report 09/08/2025 09/09/2025 FCJ PoliciesFirst Cloud Journey Bootcamp - 2025 3 - Orientation with AWS basics - Explored service categories: +Compute + Storage + Networking + Database - Collected notes on workshop rules & guidelines 09/09/2025 09/09/2025 First Cloud Journey Bootcamp - 2025 4 - Create AWS Account - Learn about AWS Budgets - Explore AWS Support - Manage access with AWS IAM: + Created IAM users and groups + Learned basics of role-based access control 09/10/2025 09/10/2025 AWS Study GroupFirst Cloud Journey Bootcamp - 2025 5 - Learned fundamentals of Amazon VPC - Studied network security using Security Groups and Network ACLs - Environment setup completed: + Created VPC & Subnet + Added Internet Gateway + Configured Route Table + Set up Security Group + Enabled VPC Flow Logs 09/11/2025 09/11/2025 AWS Study GroupFirst Cloud Journey Bootcamp - 2025 6 - Studied EC2 fundamentals: + Compared instance types and their use cases + Understood AMI (Amazon Machine Image) and its role in launching servers + Reviewed EBS (Elastic Block Store) for persistent storage - Learned multiple SSH connection approaches for EC2 instances - Explored Elastic IP and how it maintains static addressing for server 09/12/2025 09/12/2025 AWS Study GroupFirst Cloud Journey Bootcamp - 2025 7 - Practical exercises with Amazon EC2: + Deployed a new EC2 instance from an AMI + Established remote access using SSH + Attached an EBS volume and verified storage expansion + Tested basic operations to confirm connectivity and functionality 09/13/2025 09/13/2025 AWS Study GroupFirst Cloud Journey Bootcamp - 2025 8 - Performed full resource cleanup to avoid unwanted charges: + Terminated all EC2 instances (confirmed termination, noted data loss warning for instance store) + Deleted NAT Gateway and released unused Elastic IPs + Removed VPC Endpoints + Deleted VPN resources (Site-to-Site Connection, Virtual Private Gateway, Customer Gateway) + Removed VPC and associated subnets, route tables, NACLs, and security groups 09/14/2025 09/14/2025 AWS Study GroupFirst Cloud Journey Bootcamp - 2025 Week 1 Achievements: Connected with members of First Cloud Journey and understood internship policies, rules, and workplace procedures.
Learned how to structure and write the Internship Report.
Gained orientation with AWS basics and explored main service categories:
Compute Storage Networking Database Successfully created and configured an AWS Free Tier account.
Learned about AWS Budgets and explored AWS Support features.
Managed access with AWS IAM, including:
Creating IAM users and groups Learning basics of role-based access control Acquired fundamentals of Amazon VPC and studied network security using Security Groups and NACLs.
Completed environment setup:
Created VPC & Subnet Added Internet Gateway Configured Route Table Set up Security Group Enabled VPC Flow Logs Studied EC2 fundamentals, including:
Instance types and their use cases AMI (Amazon Machine Image) EBS (Elastic Block Store) for persistent storage Practiced multiple EC2 connectivity approaches (SSH, Elastic IP, EC2 Instance Connect, Session Manager).
Performed hands-on EC2 exercises:
Deployed instances from AMI Attached and expanded EBS volume Tested connectivity and basic operations Set up CloudWatch monitoring & alerts.
Performed full resource cleanup to avoid unwanted charges: terminated EC2 instances, deleted NAT Gateway, released Elastic IPs, removed VPC endpoints, VPN resources, and all associated networking components.

title: Prerequisites
content:
Before starting the workshop, ensure you have access to the following:
Accounts & Access An AWS Account IAM User with permissions to: Amazon VPC Amazon EC2 Elastic IP NAT Gateway Internet Gateway Recommended policy: AdministratorAccess (for lab purposes only) If you are using an IAM user, make sure you have access keys or console login credentials.
Cost Notice This workshop includes creating a NAT Gateway, which is a billable resource. To minimize cost, you should delete all created resources during the cleanup step.
expected workshop cost: ~ few USD if resources are cleaned up the same day
Tools Required Tool Usage AWS Management Console Main interface for building VPC, Subnets, Route Tables SSH client (PuTTY / Terminal) Used later to connect to EC2 instances Key Pair Needed for EC2 login (you will create one during the workshop) Region Selection We recommend using the region closest to you for lower latency.
Example: ap-southeast-1 (Singapore) for Vietnam users.
You must keep the same region for all steps in this workshop.

Getting familiar with AWS databases (RDS/DynamoDB) for data storage and management. Completing the basic application deployment process from EC2 ‚Üí IAM ‚Üí Storage ‚Üí Database. Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference Material 1 - Set up test environment (EC2 and S3) to check access permissions - Try granting permissions using IAM user and access key, verify connection - Switch to using IAM Role attached directly to EC2 for temporary, safer permissions - Confirm application can access AWS services without managing static keys - Cleanup created resources to avoid costs 09/15/2025 09/16/2025 AWS Study GroupFirst Cloud Journey Bootcamp - 2025 2 - Learn AWS through YouTube videos. 09/17/2025 09/17/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 3 - Attend the AWS Cloud Day Vietnam event at the office. 09/18/2025 09/18/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 4 - Learn how to use AWS technologies. 09/19/2025 09/21/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> Week 2 Achievements: Monday (15/09/2025):

Wednesday (17/09/2025):
Continued studying AWS content through instructional videos.
Became familiar with the AWS Management Console and how to access different services.
Thursday (18/09/2025):
Attended the AWS Cloud Day Vietnam 2025 event at the office.
Listened to AWS experts discuss Cloud Computing trends, AI/ML, and Digital Transformation in businesses.
Friday (19/09/2025):
Learned how to use and work with AWS technologies.
Began getting familiar with deploying and managing basic AWS services.

title: Proposal
content:
Proposal ‚Äì Smart Resume Analyzer A Unified AWS Serverless solution to analyze CVs vs JDs and generate Fit Scores
1) Executive Summary Smart Resume Analyzer is a serverless web platform that evaluates the match between a candidate‚Äôs CV and a Job Description (JD). It calculates a Fit Score, detects skill gaps, and provides personalized learning suggestions.
The solution is implemented by a 5‚Äëmember team in 4 weeks on AWS using managed, pay‚Äëas‚Äëyou‚Äëgo services to keep costs near zero for a demo workload. The UI is built with Next.js and hosted on AWS Amplify; the backend uses API Gateway + Lambda with DynamoDB, S3, Comprehend, Textract, and Cognito.
Key outcomes
90% faster CV screening for demo scenarios. Objective Fit Score with visual reports. Actionable learning roadmap per candidate. 2) Problem Statement 2.1 What‚Äôs the problem? Recruiters spend significant time manually reading CVs and comparing them to JDs. Candidates lack insight into which skills they are missing and how to improve. Existing tools are expensive or not tailored for Vietnamese/SEA use cases. 2.2 The solution Upload CV (PDF/DOCX) and JD ‚Üí automatic text extraction and NLP. Detect skills, experience, education; compute Fit Score vs JD. Recommend skill pathways mapped from a small SkillOntology store. Secure login with Cognito; results shown in a clean Next.js dashboard. 3) Solution Architecture (overview) Serverless, event‚Äëdriven architecture on AWS.
Main components
Frontend: Next.js UI (Amplify Hosting) for upload & result dashboard. API Layer: Amazon API Gateway ‚Üí AWS Lambda functions. Processing: parseResume ‚Üí Textract (if scanned PDF) ‚Üí normalized text. nlpAnalyze ‚Üí Comprehend ‚Üí entities/skills/phrases. recommendSkills ‚Üí compares to JD + SkillOntology in DynamoDB. Data: DynamoDB (results, ontology), S3 (temporary CV/JD). Identity: Cognito (JWT access tokens). Ops: IaC with AWS SAM, CI/CD via CodeBuild + CodePipeline, logging in CloudWatch. (A Mermaid architecture diagram is provided separately.)
4) Technical Implementation 4.1 Tech stack Backend: .NET 8 (C# Minimal API on Lambda) Frontend: Next.js + TailwindCSS (Amplify Hosting) AWS: Lambda, API Gateway, DynamoDB, S3, Cognito, Comprehend, Textract IaC: AWS SAM CI/CD: CodeBuild + CodePipeline 4.2 End‚Äëto‚Äëend flow User authenticates via Cognito and obtains JWT. Frontend requests presigned URL to S3 ‚Üí uploads CV/JD. API Gateway invokes Lambda parseResume: If PDF scan ‚Üí Textract ‚Üí extract text; otherwise direct parse. Clean & normalize ‚Üí store interim artifacts on S3. Lambda nlpAnalyze uses Comprehend to detect entities/skills ‚Üí writes results to DynamoDB. Lambda recommendSkills loads SkillOntology from DynamoDB ‚Üí compares CV vs JD ‚Üí computes Fit Score + gaps. Frontend queries results via API ‚Üí renders charts/tables. 4.3 Data model (DynamoDB ‚Äì simplified) Table Profiles (PK: userId, SK: profileId) ‚Äì store latest CV parse. Table Analyses (PK: analysisId) ‚Äì fit score, gaps, timestamps. Table SkillOntology (PK: skillId, attributes: name, tags, learningPath[]). 4.4 API (high level) POST /upload-url ‚Üí presign for CV/JD. POST /analyze ‚Üí triggers pipeline for a given S3 key pair. GET /analyses/{id} ‚Üí returns Fit Score & recommendations. GET /skills/{id} ‚Üí (optional) fetch a skill‚Äôs learning path. 5) Timeline & Milestones (4 weeks) Week Milestone Deliverables 1 Foundation SAM template, DynamoDB tables, Cognito, base UI 2 Parsing & NLP parseResume, nlpAnalyze, JD parsing, unit tests 3 Recommender & FE integration recommendSkills, dashboard, charts 4 Demo & hardening E2E tests, logging, cost tuning, slide deck 6) Budget Estimation (demo scale) Indicative, assuming < 500 requests/month
Lambda: ~$0.02 API Gateway: ~$0.01 S3 (few GB, low requests): ~$0.10 DynamoDB (on‚Äëdemand, low R/W): ~$0.05 Amplify Hosting: ~$0.30 Comprehend + Textract (small pages): ~$0.40 Cognito: $0.00
Total ‚âà $0.9 / month (~$10 / year) 7) Security, Risks & Mitigations Security
Private S3 buckets with SSE‚ÄëKMS; presigned uploads only. IAM least privilege; API protected by Cognito JWT. PII masking for logs; CloudWatch alarms. Optional: set lifecycle rules to delete raw CV/JD after analysis. Risks & mitigations
NLP accuracy: Provide supported formats + fallback to keyword rules. Large/unclean CVs: Validate size/format; sanitize before NLP. Cost spikes: AWS Budget alarms; cap page counts per request. 8) Expected Outcomes Automated CV‚ÄëJD matching with transparent Fit Score. Visual breakdown of skills matched vs gaps and learning roadmap. Serverless, low‚Äëops stack that‚Äôs easy to demo, extend, and localize. üìÑ Proposal Document (Google Docs) üëâ Review Proposal here:
GOOGLE DOC LINK

title: Create VPC & Subnets
content:
Create VPC & Subnets In this component, you will create your own Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) and define two subnets:
1 Public Subnet (Internet accessible) 1 Private Subnet (no direct Internet access) 3.1 Create the VPC Open AWS Management Console Navigate to Services ‚Üí VPC Click Create VPC Select VPC Only Enter the details: Name tag: Workshop-VPC IPv4 CIDR: 10.0.0.0/16 Keep all other settings at default Click Create VPC 3.2 Create Public Subnet In the left menu, click Subnets Click Create subnet Configure as follows: VPC: Workshop-VPC Subnet name: Public-Subnet Availability Zone: (any, example: ap-southeast-1a) IPv4 CIDR block: 10.0.1.0/24 Click Create subnet 3.3 Create Private Subnet Click Create subnet again Fill in the values: VPC: Workshop-VPC Subnet name: Private-Subnet Availability Zone: (can be same or different) IPv4 CIDR block: 10.0.2.0/24 Click Create subnet This process is similar to 3.2 with only minor differences. Please see the 3.2 section for reference.
3.4 Enable Auto-Assign Public IP (Only for Public Subnet) Go to Subnets Select Public-Subnet Click Actions ‚Üí Edit subnet settings Enable: ‚òë Auto-assign public IPv4 Click Save Expected result: You now have a VPC with two subnets ready to use.
Components created so far:
Resource Name CIDR VPC Workshop-VPC 10.0.0.0/16 Subnet 1 (Public) Public-Subnet 10.0.1.0/24 Subnet 2 (Private) Private-Subnet 10.0.2.0/24

title: Translated Blogs
content:
AWS Tech U Program Survival Guide This blog introduces AWS Tech U - a career acceleration program for early career talent, combining technical training and soft skills (ProSkills). It shares strategies for conquering AWS certifications from foundational to advanced levels, how to expand knowledge through Technical Field Communities (TFCs) and Shadowing activities. Finally, it outlines 4 tips for success: set high expectations, find teammates, own your schedule, and accumulate knowledge every day.
[Google Doc Link: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1L5L6djqZEsalXtBWt8WBMxRAg19RJvdMKiALMSo3DfY/edit?usp=drive_link]
Enhance contact center workforce management with new Amazon Connect Forecasting, Capacity Planning, and Scheduling features (Q2 2025) This article introduces new Amazon Connect features that optimize workforce management through AI. Key highlights include: Customizing work activities to track detailed tasks; Editing forecasts directly on the UI for quick reaction to changes; and Setting recurring activities to automate scheduling. These features help reduce operational costs and increase forecast accuracy without the need for third-party tools.
[Google Doc Link: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1J4t_JBIL2OTN9-aHAQ6MYpQuXW5CMl7aik4mKaoXjbA/edit?usp=drive_link]
Best performance and fastest memory with new Amazon EC2 R8i and R8i-flex instances AWS launches the 8th generation memory-optimized instances (R8i and R8i-flex) powered by custom Intel Xeon 6 processors. The R8i series delivers 15% better price performance and 20% higher overall performance compared to the previous generation, suitable for mission-critical workloads like Databases or Big Data. The R8i-flex version offers cost optimization (5% cheaper) for workloads that do not fully utilize compute resources. Both support the fastest memory bandwidth in the cloud.
[Google Doc Link: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Xk_y-Cb1JefYkhzjHmEc14diLfWipYGz8Xk4LkKa3b4/edit?usp=drive_link]

title: Event 3
content:
Reflection Report: ‚ÄúBuilding Agentic AI & Context Optimization‚Äù Event: Agentic AI Workshop. Date: Friday, December 5, 2025. Time: 9:00 AM ‚Äì 12:00 PM. Location: 26th Floor, Bitexco Tower, Ho Chi Minh City.
Purpose of the Event. Explore the concept of “Agentic AI” - AI that can take action. Learn techniques for context optimization in LLMs. Key Contents. Agents for Amazon Bedrock: How to define agents and action groups. RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation): Enhancing model responses with external data. Context Window Management: Strategies for handling long conversations. Key Takeaways. Agents allow LLMs to interact with internal systems and APIs. RAG is essential for keeping AI responses up-to-date and accurate. Event Experience. Fascinating to see AI performing complex multi-step tasks. The demo on “Travel Booking Agent” was very impressive.

title: Event 5
content:
Reflection Report: ‚ÄúAWS Cloud Mastery Series #3: Security on AWS‚Äù Event: AWS Cloud Mastery Series #3. Date: Saturday, November 29, 2025. Time: 8:30 AM ‚Äì 12:00 PM. Location: 26th Floor, Bitexco Tower, Ho Chi Minh City.
Purpose of the Event. Understand the Shared Responsibility Model. Learn how to secure workloads on AWS. Key Contents. IAM Best Practices: Least privilege, MFA, Roles vs Users. Network Security: VPC, Security Groups, NACLs, WAF. Data Protection: Encryption at rest (KMS) and in transit. Threat Detection: GuardDuty and Security Hub. Key Takeaways. Security is “Job Zero” at AWS. Always follow the Principle of Least Privilege. Automate security checks wherever possible. Event Experience. Eye-opening session on common security misconfigurations. The “Capture the Flag” (CTF) style mini-game was very engaging.

title: Event 6
content:
Reflection Report: ‚ÄúAWS for SAP & Generative AI‚Äù Event: AWS for SAP Using GenAI. Date: Thursday, November 20, 2025. Time: 13:00 PM ‚Äì 17:00 PM. Location: 26th Floor, Bitexco Tower, Ho Chi Minh City.
Purpose of the Event. Explore how AWS supports SAP workloads. Learn about modernizing SAP with Generative AI capabilities. Key Contents. SAP on AWS: Migration strategies and benefits. Amazon Q Developer: Using AI coding assistants for SAP ABAP development. Predictive Maintenance: Integrating IoT and ML with SAP data. Key Takeaways. AWS provides strong support for SAP infrastructure. GenAI can significantly accelerate ABAP code development and refactoring. Modernizing legacy ERP systems is easier with cloud-native tools. Event Experience. Although I am new to SAP, it was interesting to see how it integrates with modern AI tools. Good insights into enterprise-grade ERP solutions.

title: Event 4
content:
Reflection Report: ‚ÄúAWS Cloud Mastery Series #2: DevOps on AWS‚Äù Event: AWS Cloud Mastery Series #2. Date: Monday, November 17, 2025. Time: 8:30 AM ‚Äì 17:00 PM. Location: 26th Floor, Bitexco Tower, Ho Chi Minh City.
Purpose of the Event. Master DevOps practices using AWS tools. Learn about CI/CD pipelines and Infrastructure as Code. Key Contents. AWS CodeSuite: CodeCommit, CodeBuild, CodeDeploy, CodePipeline. Infrastructure as Code: Deep dive into AWS CloudFormation and CDK. Observability: Monitoring with CloudWatch and X-Ray. Key Takeaways. Automation is the heart of DevOps. CDK allows defining infrastructure using familiar programming languages (TypeScript/Python). “You build it, you run it” philosophy. Event Experience. Full-day workshop with intensive hands-on labs. Successfully built a fully automated CI/CD pipeline by the end of the day.

title: Event 2
content:
Reflection Report: ‚ÄúAWS Cloud Mastery Series #1: AI/ML/GenAI on AWS‚Äù Event: AWS Cloud Mastery Series #1. Date: Saturday, November 15, 2025. Time: 8:30 AM ‚Äì 11:30 AM. Location: 26th Floor, Bitexco Tower, 02 Hai Trieu Street, Ho Chi Minh City.
Purpose of the Event. Deep dive into AWS AI/ML services. Hands-on demonstration of GenAI capabilities. Key Contents. SageMaker Overview: Building, training, and deploying ML models at scale. Bedrock Deep Dive: Accessing foundation models via API. Hands-on Lab: Building a simple Chatbot using Bedrock. Key Takeaways. Learned how to select the right Foundation Model for specific use cases. Understood the pricing models of Bedrock and SageMaker. Gained practical experience in prompting. Event Experience. The hands-on session was very helpful in demystifying GenAI. Good interaction with the trainers.

title: Create NAT Gateway
content:
The NAT Gateway allows instances in the Private Subnet to access the Internet without being publicly exposed. This is how the private EC2 will yum install, download updates, etc.
5.1 Allocate Elastic IP In the left VPC menu, select Elastic IPs Click Allocate Elastic IP address Choose default settings Click Allocate 5.2 Create NAT Gateway In the left VPC panel, go to NAT gateways Click Create NAT gateway Configure: Field Value Name Workshop-NAT Availability mode Zonal Subnet Public-Subnet Connectivity type Public Elastic IP allocation Select the one you just created Click Create NAT gateway 5.3 Wait for NAT Gateway to become “Available” Status starts as Pending Wait until it changes to Available Result Check Resource Status NAT Gateway (Workshop-NAT) Available Elastic IP Associated You‚Äôre now ready to route private subnet traffic through NAT.

title: Week 4 Worklog
content:
Week 4 Objectives: Master S3 (Simple Storage Service). Understand Storage Classes and Lifecycle policies. Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference Material 2 - Introduction to S3 concepts (Buckets, Objects). - Create first S3 bucket. 22/09/2025 23/09/2025 3 - Learn about S3 Storage Classes (Standard, IA, Glacier). 23/09/2025 24/09/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 4 - Configure Versioning and Encryption on S3. 24/09/2025 25/09/2025 <AWS Lab 3> 5 - Implement Lifecycle Policies to move data to Glacier. 25/09/2025 26/09/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 6 - Host a Static Website on S3. 26/09/2025 27/09/2025 Week 4 Achievements Monday (22/09/2025):
Created multiple S3 Buckets via Console and CLI. Uploaded and managed objects. Tuesday (23/09/2025):
Analyzed cost differences between S3 Standard, Intelligent-Tiering, and Glacier. Wednesday (24/09/2025):
Enabled Versioning to protect against accidental deletion. Enabled Server-Side Encryption (SSE-S3). Thursday (25/09/2025):
Created a Lifecycle rule to transition objects to Glacier after 30 days. Friday (26/09/2025):
Successfully hosted a static portfolio website using S3. Configured Bucket Policy for public read access.

title: Event 1
content:
Reflection Report: ‚ÄúAWS Cloud Day Vietnam 2025 & GenAI Track‚Äù Event: AWS Vietnam Cloud Day.
Date: Thursday, September 18, 2025.
Time: 9:00 AM ‚Äì 17:00 PM (GMT+7).
Location: AWS Vietnam Office, Bitexco Financial Tower, District 1, Ho Chi Minh City.
Purpose of the Event. Introduce the latest technology trends from AWS, especially Generative AI. Share case studies from major enterprises in Vietnam and across the region. Discuss leadership strategies and organizational management in the AI era. Explore best practices for security and real-world applications of AI Agents. Key Contents. Part 1: Main Sessions (AWS Cloud Day Vietnam). Opening & Keynote: Overview of AWS‚Äôs vision in Vietnam and Southeast Asia. Customer Keynotes: Applying AI in finance and blockchain sectors. AWS Keynote: Regional tech trends and strategies to empower innovation. Part 2: GenAI Track. Building a Unified Data Foundation: Strategies for scalable AI & analytics. GenAI Adoption Roadmap: Vision and services supporting enterprise adoption. AI-Driven Development Lifecycle (AI-DLC): Integrating AI into software development. Securing GenAI Applications: Addressing security challenges in infrastructure and models. Beyond Automation - AI Agents: AI Agents as intelligent partners driving productivity. Key Takeaways. GenAI is a catalyst for organizational transformation, not just a tool. Security is fundamental and must be integrated from the ground up (Zero Trust). AI Agents represent the next leap in automation and productivity. Event Experience. Networking: Met with AWS experts and industry leaders. Learning: Gained deep insights into GenAI security and architecture. Atmosphere: Professional, energetic, and inspiring. Event Photos. (Insert photos here)

title: Launch EC2 Instances
content:
You will now deploy two EC2 instances:
Instance Subnet Access EC2-Public Public-Subnet SSH directly from Internet EC2-Private Private-Subnet No public IP ‚Äî accessible only through Public EC2 Both will use the same AMI and instance type for simplicity.
7.1 Create a Key Pair Go to EC2 Console Left panel ‚Üí Key Pairs Click Create key pair Set: Name: Workshop-Key Type: RSA Format: .pem (Linux/Mac) or .ppk (Windows PuTTY) Download and store securely This key will be used later for SSH.
7.2 Launch Public EC2 Instance In EC2 Console ‚Üí Click Instances ‚Üí Click Launch instances Name: EC2-Public Select AMI: Amazon Linux Instance type: t3.micro (Free tier eligible) Select existing key pair: Workshop-Key Network settings (Click Edit to show menu): VPC: Workshop-VPC Subnet: Public-Subnet Auto-assign Public IP: Enabled Configure security group: New SG name: Public-EC2-SG Inbound rule: Type: SSH Source Type: Custom Source: 0.0.0.0/0 Leave everything else as default. Launch instance 7.3 Launch Private EC2 Instance In EC2 Console ‚Üí Click Instances ‚Üí Click Launch instances again Name: EC2-Private AMI + instance type = same as public EC2 Use key pair: Workshop-Key Network settings: VPC: Workshop-VPC Subnet: Private-Subnet Auto-assign Public IP: Disabled Security Group: Name: Private-EC2-SG Type: SSH Source Type: Custom Source: Public-EC2-SG (not the Internet) 7.4 Verify Instances Instance IP Expected EC2-Public Has IPv4 Public Can SSH from your machine EC2-Private No Public IP Only reachable via Public EC2

title: Workshop
content:
Workshop: Building Basic AWS VPC and EC2 Infrastructure Welcome to Week 2’s practical session. In this workshop, we will build a basic network architecture on AWS.
Content Overview Prerequisites Create VPC & Subnets Create NAT Gateway Launch EC2 Instances Cleanup

title: Week 5 Worklog
content:
Week 5 Objectives: Explore Relational Databases (RDS). Explore NoSQL Databases (DynamoDB). Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference Material 2 - Introduction to RDS (MySQL/PostgreSQL). - Create an RDS instance. 29/09/2025 30/09/2025 3 - Connect EC2 to RDS. - Understand Multi-AZ and Read Replicas. 30/09/2025 01/10/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 4 - Introduction to DynamoDB. - Create a DynamoDB table. 01/10/2025 02/10/2025 <AWS Lab 4> 5 - Perform CRUD operations on DynamoDB using CLI. 02/10/2025 03/10/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 6 - Compare SQL vs NoSQL use cases. 03/10/2025 04/10/2025 Week 5 Achievements Monday (29/09/2025):
Launched a MySQL RDS instance within a private subnet. Configured Security Groups for database access. Tuesday (30/09/2025):
Successfully connected a web server (EC2) to the RDS database. Enabled Multi-AZ deployment for high availability. Wednesday (01/10/2025):
Created a DynamoDB table with Partition Key and Sort Key. Understood Read/Write Capacity Units (RCU/WCU). Thursday (02/10/2025):
Inserted and queried data in DynamoDB using AWS CLI. Friday (03/10/2025):
Analyzed scenarios suitable for Relational vs NoSQL databases. Cleaned up resources to avoid extra charges.

title: Self-Evaluation
content:
During my internship at AWS (First Cloud Journey) from September to December, I had the opportunity to learn, practice, and apply the knowledge acquired in school to a real-world working environment.
I participated in the Capstone Project, through which I improved my skills in cloud architecture, serverless development, and teamwork.
In terms of work ethic, I always strived to complete tasks well, complied with workplace regulations, and actively engaged with colleagues to improve work efficiency.
To objectively reflect on my internship period, I would like to evaluate myself based on the following criteria:
No. Criteria Description Good Fair Average 1 Professional knowledge & skills Understanding of the field, applying knowledge in practice, proficiency with tools, work quality. ‚òê ‚úÖ ‚òê 2 Ability to learn Ability to absorb new knowledge and learn quickly. ‚úÖ ‚òê ‚òê 3 Proactiveness Taking initiative, seeking out tasks without waiting for instructions. ‚úÖ ‚òê ‚òê 4 Sense of responsibility Completing tasks on time and ensuring quality. ‚úÖ ‚òê ‚òê 5 Discipline Adhering to schedules, rules, and work processes. ‚òê ‚úÖ ‚òê 6 Progressive mindset Willingness to receive feedback and improve oneself. ‚úÖ ‚òê ‚òê 7 Communication Presenting ideas and reporting work clearly. ‚òê ‚úÖ ‚òê 8 Teamwork Working effectively with colleagues and participating in teams. ‚úÖ ‚òê ‚òê 9 Professional conduct Respecting colleagues, partners, and the work environment. ‚úÖ ‚òê ‚òê 10 Problem-solving skills Identifying problems, proposing solutions, and showing creativity. ‚òê ‚úÖ ‚òê 11 Contribution to project/team Work effectiveness, innovative ideas, recognition from the team. ‚òê ‚úÖ ‚òê 12 Overall General evaluation of the entire internship period. ‚úÖ ‚òê ‚òê Needs Improvement. Communication: Need to be more confident when presenting technical ideas to a larger audience. Time Management: Sometimes got stuck too long on a single bug; need to balance time better. Deep Technical Depth: While I learned many services, I need to dive deeper into networking nuances.

title: Clean Up
content:
To avoid unnecessary charges ‚Äî especially from the NAT Gateway ‚Äî you should remove all created resources after finishing the workshop.
Follow the steps below in order:
9.1 Terminate EC2 Instances Open EC2 Console Select both EC2-Public and EC2-Private Click Instance state ‚Üí Terminate (This process may take some time) Confirm termination 9.2 Delete NAT Gateway Go to VPC Console ‚Üí NAT Gateways Select Workshop-NAT Click Actions ‚Üí Delete NAT Gateway (This process may take some time) Confirm the action Wait until NAT Gateway shows as Deleted before moving on.
9.3 Release Elastic IP After NAT Gateway is deleted:
Go to Elastic IPs Select the allocated address Click Actions ‚Üí Release Elastic IP address Confirm release (empty Elastic IP addresses list) 9.4 Detach and Delete Internet Gateway In Internet Gateways Select Workshop-IGW Click Actions ‚Üí Detach from VPC Then Actions ‚Üí Delete Internet gateway Confirm deletion (empty Internet gateways list)

title: Week 6 Worklog
content:
Week 6 Objectives: Implement Elastic Load Balancing (ELB). Configure Auto Scaling Groups (ASG). Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference Material 2 - Understand ELB types (ALB, NLB, CLB). - Create an Application Load Balancer. 06/10/2025 07/10/2025 3 - Configure Target Groups and Register Targets. 07/10/2025 08/10/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 4 - Introduction to Auto Scaling. - Create Launch Template. 08/10/2025 09/10/2025 <AWS Lab 5> 5 - Configure Auto Scaling Group with ALB. - Test scaling policies. 09/10/2025 10/10/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 6 - Stress test the architecture to trigger scaling. 10/10/2025 11/10/2025 Week 6 Achievements Monday (06/10/2025):
Differentiated between Application, Network, and Classic Load Balancers. Deployed an Application Load Balancer (ALB) facing the internet. Tuesday (07/10/2025):
Configured Target Groups and health checks. Verified traffic distribution across multiple EC2 instances. Wednesday (08/10/2025):
Created a Launch Template defining the configuration for new instances. Thursday (09/10/2025):
Set up an Auto Scaling Group spanning multiple Availability Zones. Integrated ASG with the Load Balancer. Friday (10/10/2025):
Performed a stress test; observed new instances launching automatically as CPU load increased. Verified instances terminating when load decreased.

title: Feedback
content:
Here, you can freely share your personal opinions and experiences during the First Cloud Journey program.
Overall Evaluation 1. Working Environment
The working environment at FCJ is incredibly supportive. I felt welcomed from day one. The open-office layout fosters collaboration, although it can sometimes get a bit noisy during peak hours.
2. Support from Mentors
My mentors were outstanding. They didn’t just give me the answers; they guided me on how to find them myself. Their industry insights were invaluable.
3. Relevance to Career Goals
This internship perfectly matched my goal of becoming a Cloud Architect. The hands-on labs and real-world projects bridged the gap between my academic theory and industry practice.
4. Skill Development
I significantly improved my AWS technical skills, specifically in serverless architectures. I also learned soft skills like time management and effective communication.
Additional Questions What are you most satisfied with? The access to premium AWS learning resources and the opportunity to attend exclusive events like the Cloud Day.
What should be improved? Perhaps more structured documentation for the initial project setup would be helpful for new joiners.
Would you recommend this internship? Absolutely. It’s a fast-track to learning Cloud Computing properly.
Suggestions Improvement: Organize more technical deep-dive sessions on specific advanced topics like Advanced Networking or Security. Future: I hope to stay connected with the FCJ community. Thank you, FCJ Team, for this amazing journey!

title: Week 7 Worklog
content:
Week 7 Objectives: Advanced Networking (VPC Peering, Route 53). Review for Midterm Exam. Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference Material 2 - Configure VPC Peering between two VPCs. 13/10/2025 14/10/2025 3 - Learn about Route 53 (DNS records, Routing policies). 14/10/2025 15/10/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 4 - Review Core Services: EC2, S3, IAM, VPC. 15/10/2025 16/10/2025 5 - Review Database and HA/Scaling concepts. 16/10/2025 17/10/2025 6 - Take practice tests / Mock Exam. 17/10/2025 18/10/2025 Week 7 Achievements Monday (13/10/2025):
Established VPC Peering connection between separate VPCs. Updated Route Tables to allow traffic flow across peers. Tuesday (14/10/2025):
Registered a domain name using Route 53. Configured A, CNAME, and Alias records. Wednesday (15/10/2025):
Consolidated knowledge on Compute, Storage, and Security. Clarified doubts regarding IAM Roles vs Policies. Thursday (16/10/2025):
Reviewed architecture diagrams for High Availability. Re-visited RDS Multi-AZ and Read Replica differences. Friday (17/10/2025):
Completed a full-length mock exam with a passing score. Identified weak areas for final revision.

title: Week 8 Worklog
content:
Week 8 Objectives: Midterm Examination. Post-exam review and analysis. Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference Material 2 - Final revision of key concepts. 20/10/2025 21/10/2025 3 - MIDTERM EXAM DAY. 21/10/2025 21/10/2025 - 4 - Rest and recovery. 22/10/2025 22/10/2025 - 5 - Review exam answers and mistakes. 23/10/2025 24/10/2025 6 - Introduction to upcoming project phase. 24/10/2025 25/10/2025 Week 8 Achievements Monday (20/10/2025):
Conducted a quick-fire revision session with peers. Tuesday (21/10/2025):
Successfully sat for the Midterm Exam. Managed time effectively during the test. Wednesday (22/10/2025):
Took a break to recharge. Thursday (23/10/2025):
Discussed exam questions with mentors. Understood the reasoning behind incorrect answers. Friday (24/10/2025):
Received briefing on the Final Capstone Project. Started brainstorming project ideas.

title: Week 9 Worklog
content:
Week 9 Objectives: Explore Serverless Computing. Build APIs with API Gateway and Lambda. Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference Material 2 - Introduction to AWS Lambda. - Create first Lambda function. 27/10/2025 28/10/2025 3 - Learn about API Gateway. - Integrate API Gateway with Lambda. 28/10/2025 29/10/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 4 - Understand Event-Driven Architecture. - S3 Event Notifications to Lambda. 29/10/2025 30/10/2025 <AWS Lab 6> 5 - Introduction to Step Functions for orchestration. 30/10/2025 31/10/2025 6 - Build a serverless backend for the Capstone Project. 31/10/2025 01/11/2025 Week 9 Achievements Monday (27/10/2025):
Wrote Python code in Lambda console. Understood Lambda pricing (duration & memory). Tuesday (28/10/2025):
Created a REST API using API Gateway. Successfully triggered Lambda via HTTP request. Wednesday (29/10/2025):
Configured S3 to trigger a Lambda function upon file upload (image resizing use case). Thursday (30/10/2025):
Explored Step Functions state machines to coordinate multiple Lambdas. Friday (31/10/2025):
Drafted the architecture for the serverless components of the final project.

title: Week 10 Worklog
content:
Week 10 Objectives: Monitoring & Logging (CloudWatch, CloudTrail). Infrastructure as Code (CloudFormation). Tasks to be carried out this week: Day Task Start Date Completion Date Reference Material 2 - Configure CloudWatch Alarms and Dashboards. 03/11/2025 04/11/2025 3 - Analyze logs with CloudWatch Logs Insights. 04/11/2025 05/11/2025 <Youtube: AWS Study Group> 4 - Audit API calls using CloudTrail. 05/11/2025 06/11/2025 <AWS Lab 7> 5 - Introduction to CloudFormation. - Write a simple YAML template. 06/11/2025 07/11/2025 6 - Deploy Project Infrastructure using CloudFormation. 07/11/2025 08/11/2025 Week 10 Achievements Monday (03/11/2025):
Created a CloudWatch Dashboard to monitor EC2 CPU and Memory. Set up an Alarm to send SNS notifications when CPU > 80%. Tuesday (04/11/2025):
Used Log Insights to query application logs. Wednesday (05/11/2025):
Enabled CloudTrail to track user activity and API usage for security auditing. Thursday (06/11/2025):
Learned the syntax of CloudFormation (Resources, Parameters, Outputs). Deployed a simple S3 bucket stack via code. Friday (07/11/2025):
Started converting the manual project setup into CloudFormation templates for reproducibility.
